Hand Attachments Prefab¶

The Hand Attachments prefab provides a hand model that exposes the major transforms of the parts of a hand. The transforms include:

  • Palm – the center of the palm
  • Arm – the center of the arm
  • Thumb – the tip of the thumb
  • PinchPoint – a position halfway between the index finger tip and the tip of the thumb
  • Index – the tip of the index finger
  • Middle – the tip of the middle finger
  • Ring – the tip of the ring finger
  • Pinky – the tip of the little finger
  • GrabPoint – a point near the center of the finger tips and the wrist position

Using the Hand Attachments Prefab¶

To use the hand attachments prefab, add a pair of the HandAttachments prefabs to the Hand Pool:

  1. Drag a pair of HandAttachments prefabs into the scene.
  2. Set one prefab to Left Handedness and the other to Right. (It helps to rename the game objects to keep track of which is which.)
  3. On the scene’s LeapHandController, increase the Hand Pool’s Model Pool size by one. This will create an additional element in the pool.
  4. Set the name of the new element to “utility_hands” (or any suitable name).
  5. Drag the HandAttachments from the scene hierarchy to the left and right model properties in the Hand Pool element that you just created.
  6. Set Is Enabled and Can Duplicate to true, if desired.
  7. Add additional components and child game objects to the attachment points.

Note: you can remove the child transforms for any attachment points that you are not using from the HandAttachments script. This optimization will releave Unity from having to modify the unused transforms.

You can also make a prefab out of your completed HandAttachments game object. In that case, you can put the prefab into the Hand Pool directly and do not need a version in the scene hierarchy.

Key Components¶

The key components in the Hand Attachments prefab include:

Hand Enable Disable (Script)¶

The HandEnableDisable script turns the entire hand attachment object off by calling SetActive(false) when the physical hand leaves the Leap Motion field of view. The script does the opposite when a hand enters the field of view.

Hand Attachments (Script)¶

The HandAttachments script is an IHandModel that updates the child transforms each frame based on the current positions and rotations of the hand and fingers reported in the Leap Motion tracking data.

The script provides a list of transforms for each supported attachment point. You should set the transform to None for any unused points. The transforms assigned here are positioned directly. You can add child transforms to the attachment points to position objects at an offset position from the base positions.

The Handedness setting must be set to Left or Right.

Child Transforms¶

The HandAttachments prefab contains an empty GameObject for each of the attachment points. These game objects consist of a Unity Transform, which is updated based on the tracked hand, and an AttachmentController component.

The AttachmentController script can be used to control child objects of an attachment point. The script has two methods, Activate() and Deactivate() that you can call via a standard Unity event listener (or another script). For example, you can use the OnActivate and OnDeactivate events of a Detector to turn attachments on or off.

The AttachmentController has two properties:

  • Deactivate On Disable – disables all children when the hand model is disabled. This should be on when using a transition, but off if you want the attachments to be on all the time.
  • Transition – An ITransition object. If set, the AttachmentController will play the transition when turning attachments on and off in response to the Activate() and Deactivate() functions.

Note: if your attached child objects are always enabled, you can remove the AttachmentController from the attachment point.
